bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, May 14, 1921

div1.p: Carter believes that yellow fever is still present in Africa. Carter would be willing to go to Africa as an adviser if he is physically able.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, May 14, 1921
div1.opener:
/LC
R
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
May 14, 1921.
Africa
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p: I have been thinking about the African situation:

1/ In spite of no cases having been reported since 1919, it
is very improbable that yellow fever has ceased to exist in Africa.

2/ Because of the fact that no cases have been reported since
1919 it is equally improbable that it has not undergone considera-
ble diminution from what existed during the years covered by the
reports of the British West African Yellow Fever Commission--doubt-
less due to the causes enumerated by Noble and Guiteras.

3/ These postulates taken together indicate the present as a
time of election for a campaign for the elimination of yellow fever
because (a) the work would now be most efficacious and (b) if not
eliminated, or at least controlled, now, the accumulation of unac-
climated people now going on, on the Coast especially (Noble) should
lead to a decidedly wider spread of the fever than now exists.

You stated that personnel was lacking to initiate the African
work, all available being needed for that going on in Mexico: Cen-
tral America and Peru and for the protection of Guayaquil.

Admitting the impossibility of sending another Commission to
Africa, could not the British local authorities be induced to take
the one measure at once feasible and necessary for the elimination
of yellow fever? It is this: To press a Stegomyia campaign in all
large towns and in such smaller ones as (a) from their position or
2
position or
travel routes are especially liable to be sources of infection and
(b) those in which susceptible people are apt to gather.

This should be done without regard to the existence of yellow
fever at such places. If the Stegomyia in them can be so decreased
that yellow fever will not propagate in them when introduced, I
think we may safely trust it to eliminate itself spontaneously from
the smaller places, or--at the worst--to smoulder along in such
places until one has time to go after it.

Of course, the report of an outbreak in any small place should
be the occasion for immediate Stegomyia control there and inspection
of places in close communication therewith, but even without this
(which is not really necessary) the method outlined will surely
control--i. e. prevent, serious spread of-the fever and not probably eli-
minate it.

The British local authorities can, I am sure, do this as well
as anyone else; only it maybe that they have not thought of it. As
I have outlined it, it is an entomological and administrative problem
only and requires no experience with yellow fever. Should the local
authorities then undertake this work I see no reason why they should
not succeed in it without outside assistance.

If any be needed it would be minimal and I would be willing,
and I believe able, to go and advise on such points as might be
necessary, and I must confess that there are some few points--and
important ones--in the control of breeding not yet in any book I
have seen. I would not have to do any field work, but simply ad-
vise as to the work to be done and especially as to how it should
be done. Also, I would be available as a clinician for the diagno-
sis of doubtful cases--some of which are impossible of diagnosis.

Whether if this suggestion were made to them the local author-
ities would undertaken this work, I do not know. If you think they
would, it might be advisable to suggest it to them.

The above is primarily a suggestion as to how this work may
possibly be done without interfering with the American work, which
unquestionably should have precedence.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. May 15, 1921.
P. S. Whether I would be physically capable of undertaking the
work above outlined for myself--which is not hard work--may be a
question, and whether, if I am, I could not be better utilized in
Peru is another question.
For the first, I am going into hospital within a few days
for physical examination to get an opinion on my condition--which,
frankly, does not seem as good as on arrival. Am not quite used
to civilization again, I think.
For the second, you must judge.
